Before buying the game:
This is my review after 23 hours of gameplay. (Don‚Äôt pay too much attention to the negative comments about the subscription.) Being 100% honest and critical, here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve noticed so far:

The game is fun. If you‚Äôre a player like me who enjoys sandbox-style games, this one‚Äôs for you. The leveling system is simple and interesting, which makes it enjoyable. The community is friendly and chill. The clan system is quite interesting (I‚Äôve been playing solo the whole time, but I‚Äôve seen a lot of unity and cooperation within clans).

Like any game, it has its problems. The performance isn‚Äôt ideal, but if you have a mid-to-high-end PC, you should be able to run it just fine. I‚Äôm a very visual person ‚Äî I enjoy graphics and detail ‚Äî and visually the game has some bugs and rendering issues. Nothing game-breaking, but if you‚Äôre like me, they might bother you from time to time.

Sensitive topic:
Subscription. Personally, I don‚Äôt see it as a problem. Every game needs to be self-sustaining. The cheapest subscription that includes a plot costs around $6 ‚Äî probably what you‚Äôd spend on a couple of sodas and a snack. Most negative comments about it come from people who want a completely free game with full access, and that‚Äôs simply not sustainable unless the game includes heavy monetization. I much prefer this system over aggressive gacha mechanics or battle passes.

I don‚Äôt consider it Pay-to-Win. Yes, you do gain XP faster if you pay, but this isn‚Äôt a competitive game, so there‚Äôs no real advantage over other players. And sure, it‚Äôs not ideal that if you stop paying, you lose your constructions ‚Äî but it‚Äôs also a way to keep the world clean from abandoned plots (think of it as a wipe). You can always come back later and build something new.

Some ping problems but nothing important.

Conclusion:
Totally worth it ‚Äî and very much so. The devs are actively releasing updates, and as long as the game continues to receive maintenance, it will keep being worth your time.

- Jewelcrafting provides ZERO benefit to your character.

- There are no automated systems available for gathering basic materials like gneiss (stone).  They need to pull some cards out of the myth of empires playbook and allow players to hire npcs to run makeshift mines so that the player can get resources without spending 1 billion hours on gathering the basic stuff. 
- Some skills are infinitely harder to level up.  Blacksmithing for example takes FOREVER, to max blacksmithing you are legitamitally looking at 700 hours of playtime but other things like carpentry you can get to end game in 1 evening.  Make that make sense.
- THE SERVERS SUCK ASSSSSSSSSSS    you will be fighting a boar and it WILL teleport on your face. [EDIT: THIS HAS GREATLY IMPROVED AND MOSTLY BEEN PATCHED OUT]

Honestly I could go on, there is a LOT to be desired in PD BUT even so the game is still very very fun and I am really looking forward to content updates and I pray the devs can learn to focus on what is important and not on stupid sht like pvp content that next to nobody partakes in. 

Also, many of the other reviews are talking about subscriptions, they are no longer required to own a plot.  You can earn a plot in game, for free.

Pax Dei is not a game for everyone ‚Äî and that doesn‚Äôt make it a bad game.
It‚Äôs true that it still needs polishing and has plenty of bugs, but the core concept is fresh, ambitious, and genuinely interesting.

It reminds me of the early days of Rust: a niche survival sandbox, full of grind, heavy farming, mixed reviews, and a rough start. Over time, Rust improved drastically, the community grew, and the game became solid. Pax Dei is going through that same early stage.

Many negative reviews mention that the game is demanding, slow to progress, not friendly for solo players, or that it feels empty. But it‚Äôs essential to understand something: Pax Dei is built around cooperation.
In a clan, everything becomes easier. Specialization makes the game flow: warriors who never craft, blacksmiths forging full-time, farmers, brewers, cooks, tailors‚Ä¶ everyone contributes. It‚Äôs almost like real life: shared roles building something bigger.

The goal is not to wander alone with a tiny cabin ‚Äîalthough you can‚Äî but to create towns and build a living world.
As a sandbox, it offers much more than PvP or city-building: it‚Äôs also a great environment for roleplay, which gives the world depth and helps players generate their own emergent lore.

This is a niche game focused on letting the community create its own world, its specialized characters, and its way of interacting. You are not the ‚Äúall-powerful hero‚Äù of traditional MMOs. Here, you need others.
That old-school feeling ‚Äîjoining Discord, organizing tasks, helping your clan, building together‚Äî is exactly what gives the game its charm.

The fun comes from watching your clan grow, your town expand, and your characters develop. The lore isn‚Äôt explicit; it‚Äôs something you discover by exploring and engaging with the world.

For players who enjoy specialization, grinding, medieval fantasy, building, and meaningful social interaction, this game offers a lot. It‚Äôs demanding, yes, but it also helps you meet people, create communities, and build real bonds through gameplay.

If the developers continue improving it and make solid decisions, I believe Pax Dei can follow Rust‚Äôs path: better mechanics, better performance, a stronger community, and a game that will feel much more complete in the coming years.

It‚Äôs not a game for everyone, but for its audience it already is ‚Äîand can become even more‚Äî a unique, innovative, and refreshing experience. In an industry where we are almost always lone superheroes, Pax Dei dares to bet on community, cooperation, and building something together. And that risk is exactly what makes it special.

You can build anything: cottages, taverns, gothic mansions, sprawling castles. The creativity they allow is staggering. Every wall, roof, and beam feels handcrafted. It doesn‚Äôt just look good, it feels good to build in this game. For a builder at heart, Pax Dei is a dream come true.

But here's the thing.

Once you get past the honeymoon phase, the reality sets in: Pax Dei is one long, slow grind. And I don't just mean a casual grind, 5-10 hours  just to move up one level in one crafting skill once you're past level 13 or so.

Combat? It's Fine, But Shallow.

The combat system is very basic. Right-click to block. Left-click to swing. You get six skills based on your equipped armor, but they‚Äôre not flashy, dynamic, or deep. There‚Äôs no dodging or rolling. No parrying. No hit reactions that make you feel like you‚Äôre in a fight.

It works, but that's all I can say. It's functional. There's potential, but right now it feels placeholder for something to do between gathering runs, not something to build a character around.

The AI and PvE? Not Much There Yet.

NPCs are dumb. Their AI is about as complex as a training dummy with legs. They run at you, swing, repeat. There are only a few types of animals to hunt, deer, wolves, bears, badgers, goats, and boars. That‚Äôs it.

No birds. No fish. No ambient wildlife. And there‚Äôs no fishing mechanic, despite having beautiful lakes and rivers. The world looks alive, but it doesn't feel alive once you interact with it.

PvP? Full Loot, but Mostly a Zerg Fest.

PvP exists, but only in designated zones. It‚Äôs full-loot, meaning if you kill someone, you can take all their gear. Sounds intense, right? But unless you‚Äôre wearing high-tier gear, you‚Äôre not going to win those fights.

If you're in iron gear and someone else is in wrought iron or steel, you‚Äôre toast. Even if you get their loot, you can‚Äôt use it unless your skills are high enough. So the reward is limited. And from what I‚Äôve seen, most PvP ends up being chaotic zerg rushing with people spamming skills and swinging wildly.

The Grind is the Game, Because There‚Äôs Nothing Else

This is the heart of the issue.

At first, crafting feels satisfying. You‚Äôre unlocking new benches, new gear, new recipes. But once you pass level 11‚Äì12 in most professions, the XP curve spikes hard. To go from level 11 to 12 in Weaponsmithing, you need around 12,300 XP. Not bad, right?

Well, by level 25‚Äì26, you're looking at 150,000+ XP per level.

Most crafts give between 200‚Äì400 XP per item, if you‚Äôre lucky. That means hundreds of high-cost items just to gain a single level, and you can also fail the craft giving 20xp, and loss of the materials and that‚Äôs after gathering, smelting, refining, and crafting components for hours upon hours.

The problem? That‚Äôs intentional.

There‚Äôs not much to do once you‚Äôve built your base and crafted your gear. The AI isn‚Äôt deep. The combat isn‚Äôt engaging. PvP is limited and niche. There are no real dungeons, no real exploration systems, no world events, no group content worth planning around.

So what do they give you? The grind.

The crafting loop is the game. It‚Äôs not a supplement, it‚Äôs the main attraction. And for someone like me who enjoys building and progression, that‚Äôs fine to a point. But the higher I climb, the more I realize:

"This grind isn‚Äôt here to challenge me. It‚Äôs here to fill the gap where gameplay should be."

And what's worse,  the grind isn‚Äôt even rewarding. You don‚Äôt gather more resources as you upgrade your tools, you just unlock access to new nodes. A bronze pick lets you mine impure iron. An iron pick lets you mine iron. A wrought iron pick lets you mine pure iron. But if you go back and mine copper or tin with a wrought iron pick? You get the same amount as with bronze. There's no tiered benefit or efficiency scaling, just gated access. That feels like a huge design miss.

Even the game‚Äôs monetization feels misaligned. I was a founder. I paid $100 during alpha. Supposedly that came with four plots but now I have to pay a subscription just to use the four I already bought. Otherwise, I get one free grace plot. It‚Äôs frustrating. There's no real benefit to having bought in early except a few cosmetic labels. No permanent advantage for supporting the game early on. That stings.

And now that I look at the numbers? As of today,  exactly one month after 1.0 release: Pax Dei has only 2,546 players in-game. That‚Äôs alarmingly low. I‚Äôm genuinely concerned for this game‚Äôs future. I doubt it will still be online in two years. Maybe not even one.

The grind, the lack of content, the shallow combat, the subscription model, they all combine into a player experience that doesn‚Äôt give back what it asks. And that‚Äôs coming from someone who‚Äôs already dumped 287 hours into this world. Everything in this game takes so much time it's mind boggling, and even just moving around takes forever as mounts are not in the game. 

Final Thoughts

Pax Dei is beautiful. It‚Äôs creative. It‚Äôs full of potential. But it‚Äôs not a finished game. It‚Äôs a stunning canvas with a basic sketch of a game loop laid on top.

If they ever expand the PvE, add real enemy AI, bring in more wildlife, introduce fishing, mounts, flesh out the skill trees, improve combat, and give players something to do besides gather and craft, this could be one of the greatest sandbox MMOs ever made.

But right now?

It‚Äôs the prettiest grind machine I‚Äôve ever played.

And if that grind ever did loosen up, the whole thing might collapse under its own emptiness.

 A solo crafter who's seen what lies past the iron wall.

Pax Dei: tu vitium et maeror
Your flaw and sorrow.

I thought long and hard to name this review, just as I often wondered throughout the game where to build, what to do next, and whether the game had a place for a person like me, a stoic builder who loves the premise of self sufficiency and solo play merged with the joy of helping others and being a good samaritan.  I'm someone who truly appreciates beauty and art in games,  and marvels when I find a game that makes me stand on a hill and think 'Wow, this is quite something'.  Pax Dei sadly only did the latter.

The breathtaking vistas, gorgeous valleys and relaxing music set me up for a world in which the player had agency, and the player could enjoy that escape from reality where they could just build, enjoy and communicate. However, what I saw from day one was less an adventure through a bustling region filled with small holdings and mini towns, but more a landscape of ghosts.  Stone and timber revenants partially exposed and never completed.  

In a game as vast as Pax Dei, I hoped there'd be less abandoned buildings and more players on the horizon.  Sadly, that was rarely the case. 

Those ruins were everywhere. The sad tale of adventurers who arrived with the same hope I did, and left feeling that the world was not theirs and even if they could claim their land - they would never be able to truly master it due to the enormous mountain of grinding needed to create not just a plot, but a home.

The 'memorials to the fallen' are endless, and this should tell you all one really needs to know. When the majority of people don't even build a roof over their head before calling it quits, there's a problem.  

Pax Dei sells itself as a fantasy sandbox world in which emergent gameplay creates the rise and fall of empires who will fight for the 'chosen lands' in the middle of the map.

The reality is that this sort of gameplay involves mostly large clans, and statistically - large clans are the minority. Pax Dei scaled experience, and resources to an absurdly low level to slow progression. The reality, as proven in games like Last Oasis, Rust, Ark, Eve, Myth of Empires is that this almost never works, because large clans are organised, methodical and experienced in getting things done, systems be damned.

The end result is these pacing systems end up only hurting the people who join solo or in groups of two or three players, and it saps any sense of achievement or sense of pride they have in the game. As a result, large organised groups power ahead, and smaller groups and individuals wither and quit.

Combat should be a dance of life to death, but it ends up being a struggle against stability due to poor design. Progress and rewards are also so tedious that it becomes frustrating. With successive updates - the devs have slowly reduced rewards and loot from NPCs that small groups can battle and today - the only thing of value on them is gold with which you can use to pay for one plot (via grace).

But - the most heartbreaking thing of all, is that as a solo player - I have no agency.  My life is to farm. 
Run to resources.
Gather resources.
Fill furnace.
Craft.
Gather logs for furnace.
Repeat.
Session over.

My heroic deeds were giving the furnace a middle finger, and smiting a boar. I gifted a newbie a set of armour, but I'm not sure he'll play long enough to need to replace it.

So. the title stands.
Pax Dei - your flaw and sorrow. The flaw is the world whose systems deny the very agency it promises for players. A world in which you become part of the machine or you are eaten by the machine. The sorrow is in the beauty of the world, spoiled by a vision which tries to be everything, but excels at nothing but attrition.

After 400 hours here is my official Pax Dei review.

Although it released as "version 1.0", it is nowhere near the quality of a full release. If I had to put a label on it, it would be barely past Alpha. Some systems don't work at all (jewelry), and the numbers required for just about everything don't seem to make sense. The game is unbelievably grindy. So much so, that the feeling of even reaching a new crafting level just doesn't hit as it should. you'll be grinding thousands of the same resources just to climb a single level, and some resources are so scarce and possibly far away from where you put your base, that it becomes extremely disheartening. 

There is teleportation, but that is also not a very good option as it uses a special resource called "grace". you get not even 1 teleport worth of grace for free per day, which means you have to grind gold to buy grace, with each next amount you buy getting exponentially more expensive. It's only really viable to buy a couple of tiers of grace, which is better spent on other things than teleporting. That's not even considering the fact that grace is required to upkeep your base every month so it doesn't disappear if you want to play for free. And free is a stretch since you paid to play the game! 

Furthermore, as I have the premium buff because my friend gave me the game from his founder pack, the game is even MORE grindy if you don't have premium. I 'm already getting tired of the grind. I can't imagine how much worse it is without premium status. Anyway, this game is not yet worth it. I'm glad I didn't have to pay for it, but feel really bad for those that did. 

The only redeeming quality is the building is very in depth, and you can make some nice things if you're artistic. My map has someone who put a giant sword monument on top of a mountain, and there's some impressive castles. One person made a bird nest with a bird overwatching it. Very impressive! However that's all there is to do in the game. Build or farm relentlessly. There's PvP as well, but don't even think about it unless you make friends and upgrade a couple tiers of gear.

As for the crafting, besides what I already mentioned, The devs have two very large problems. The stacks of everything are too small, forcing you to make hundreds of chests just to keep up, and that's with the special founder chests! the normal chests are even smaller. There is another larger chest later that is just as big as the founder one, but that takes a while to get to. The stacks need to be much greater. It's very difficult to organize things. The other issue, is the cost of materials to craft things make no sense. You need A LOT of wood to make charcoal. Like, A LOT. charcoal is used to make ingots. And often times, ingots are used to make bars. And then those bars are used to craft. So it takes multiple stacks of iron for example, to make 1 synth, to get 0.1% exp towards a level. And iron is kind of scarce in my area. Especially if other people are looking for iron, which they are. Someone has to tweak these numbers to make sense.

Next the player trading system. ... What the hell is even this? This has to be the single most frustrating thing in the entire game. You can open the market menu from your menu, which allows you to see what people are selling in their markets. There's no search feature, so you have to scroll endlessly until you find what you want. IF you find what you want, you then have to travel to their base, and then when you get to their base, find where they placed their market stall. This system is a gigantic mess and borderline unusable. It's unbelievably difficult to find certain things unless you want to spend tens of minutes scrolling through pages. Firstly, this needs a search feature. and second, you need to be able to buy things directly from the market screen. There's enough tedium in the game. Trading between players should at least be easily accomplished.

Some materials such as cotton are only in 1 or 2 places on the entire map. This could be 2 or 3 zones away. With all of that being said, this game does have potential, but I think the developers need to take care of main complaints of the community first rather than barreling ahead with new features no one is asking for.
